idAbs.para: This tool adds a new subtype to the subtypes in the input table.

summary.para: This tool adds a new subtype to the subtypes in the input table.

pythonReference.para: The feature class or table containing the subtype definition to be updated

dialogReference.para: The feature class or table containing the subtype definition to be updated

pythonReference.para: A unique integer value for the subtype to be added

dialogReference.para: A unique integer value for the subtype to be added

pythonReference.para: A description of the subtype code

dialogReference.para: A description of the subtype code

bullet_item.para: A field in the feature class or table must be assigned as the subtype field before new subtypes can be added. This is done using the tool.
If you add a subtype whose code already exists, the new subtype will be ignored.
If you need to change the description of an existing subtype, you would first have to , then add a new subtype with the same code and a new description.
The subtypes of a feature class or table can also be managed in ArcCatalog. Subtypes can be created and modified using the Subtypes Property tab on the dataset's Properties dialog box.

scriptExample.title: Add Subtype example (Python window)
scriptExample.para: The following Python window script demonstrates how to use the AddSubtype function in Immediate mode.
scriptExample.code: import arcpy from arcpy import env env.workspace = "C:/data/Montgomery.gdb" arcpy.SetSubtypeField_management("water/fittings", "TYPECODE") arcpy.AddSubtype_management("water/fittings", "1", "Bend")

scriptExample.title: Add Subtype example 2 (Stand-alone script)
scriptExample.para: The following stand-alone script demonstrates how to use the AddSubtype function as part of a workflow to add subtypes to a field.
scriptExample.code:
# Name: ManageSubtypes.py # Purpose: Create a subtype definition # Author: ESRI
# Import system modules import arcpy from arcpy import env
try: # Set the workspace (to avoid having to type in the full path to the data every time) env.workspace = "C:/data/Montgomery.gdb"
# Set local parameters inFeatures = "water/fittings"
# Process: Set Subtype Field... arcpy.SetSubtypeField_management(inFeatures, "TYPECODE")
# Process: Add Subtypes... # Store all the suptype values in a dictionary with the subtype code as the "key" and the # subtype description as the "value" (stypeDict[code]) stypeDict = {"0": "Unknown", "1": "Bend", "2": "Cap", "3": "Cross", "4": "Coupling",\ "5": "Expansion joint", "6": "Offset", "7":"Plug", "8": "Reducer",\ "9": "Saddle", "10": "Sleeve", "11": "Tap", "12": "Tee", "13": "Weld", "14": "Riser"}
# use a for loop to cycle through the dictionary for code in stypeDict: arcpy.AddSubtype_management(inFeatures, code, stypeDict[code])
# Process: Set Default Subtype... arcpy.SetDefaultSubtype_management(inFeatures, "4")
except Exception, e: # If an error occurred, print line number and error message import traceback, sys tb = sys.exc_info()[2] print "Line %i" % tb.tb_lineno print e.message
